qti-assessment-item.title: Constitutional Interpretation in Bostock v. Clayton County

qti-item-body.p: This is an excerpt from the Court's opinion in Bostock v. Clayton County (2020).

blockquote.p: Ours is a society of written laws. Judges are not free to overlook plain statutory commands on the strength of nothing more than suppositions about intentions or guesswork about expectations. In Title VII, Congress adopted broad language making it illegal for an employer to rely on an employee's sex when deciding to fire that employee. We do not hesitate to recognize today a necessary consequence of that legislative choice: An employer who fires an individual merely for being gay or transgender defies the law.

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: What method of constitutional interpretation did Justice Gorsuch use in this opinion?
qti-choice-interaction.qti-simple-choice: History This type of constitutional interpretation would have had Justice Gorsuch looking at the historical context of the law. Instead, he points out how time has changed the interpretation of this law.

Precedent When a judge uses precedent as a constitutional interpretation method, they take rulings in old cases and apply them to new cases. Justice Gorsuch does not refer to previous decisions in this excerpt of the majority opinion.
Structure Justice Gorsuch does not mention the structure of the Constitution or any of its provisions to reach this decision.
Prudence Justice Gorsuch takes into account the real-world consequences of this decision. The Court is broadening the protections included in the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

qti-content-body.p: Correct! Justice Gorsuch used prudential interpretation, considering the practical consequences of the Court's decision. By extending Title VII protections to LGBTQ+ employees, the Court acknowledged how societal understanding has evolved while applying the law's plain language to modern circumstances.

Not quite. Look at how Justice Gorsuch focuses on the "necessary consequence" of applying Title VII's language. He's not examining history, precedent, or constitutional structure, but rather considering the practical impact of interpreting the law's "broad language" in today's context.
